questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: In the three-column concept of spinal stability, which structures are part of the anterior column?
options: A. Posterior vertebral body, posterior disc, posterior longitudinal ligament
C. Anterior longitudinal ligament, anterior vertebral body, anterior disc
D. Ligamentum flavum, spinous ligaments, erector spinae
questions.correctAnswer: C. Anterior longitudinal ligament, anterior vertebral body, anterior disc

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: In the three-column concept, which structures are part of the middle column?
options: A. Posterior vertebral body, posterior disc, posterior longitudinal ligament
C. Anterior longitudinal ligament, anterior vertebral body, anterior disc
D. Ligamentum flavum, spinous ligaments, erector spinae
questions.correctAnswer: A. Posterior vertebral body, posterior disc, posterior longitudinal ligament

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: In the three-column concept, which structures are part of the posterior column?
options: A. Posterior vertebral body, posterior disc, posterior longitudinal ligament
B. Bony features (processes, lamina, pedicles), ligamentum flava, spinous ligaments, muscles
C. Anterior longitudinal ligament, anterior vertebral body, anterior disc
D. Intervertebral foramen and spinal nerves
questions.correctAnswer: B. Bony features (processes, lamina, pedicles), ligamentum flava, spinous ligaments, muscles

questions.question: Why do disc herniations commonly occur posterolaterally rather than directly posteriorly?
options: A. The anterior longitudinal ligament is weak.
B. The posterior longitudinal ligament prevents direct posterior herniation.
C. The ligamentum flavum pushes the disc sideways.
D. The nucleus pulposus naturally shifts laterally.
questions.correctAnswer: B. The posterior longitudinal ligament prevents direct posterior herniation.

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: In the cervical spine, a disc herniation typically compresses the nerve root exiting at which level relative to the herniation?
options: A. The nerve root exiting at the same level (e.g., C5-C6 herniation compresses C6 root)
B. The nerve root exiting one level below (e.g., C5-C6 herniation compresses C7 root)
C. The nerve root exiting one level above (e.g., C5-C6 herniation compresses C5 root)
D. The nerve root exiting two levels below
questions.correctAnswer: A. The nerve root exiting at the same level (e.g., C5-C6 herniation compresses C6 root)

questions.passage: This question does not have a passage.
questions.question: In the lumbar spine, due to the course of the nerve roots, a posterolateral disc herniation typically compresses the nerve root exiting at which level relative to the herniation?
options: A. The nerve root exiting at the same level (e.g., L4-L5 herniation compresses L4 root)
B. The nerve root exiting one level below (e.g., L4-L5 herniation compresses L5 root)
C. The nerve root exiting one level above (e.g., L4-L5 herniation compresses L3 root)
D. The nerve root exiting two levels below
questions.correctAnswer: B. The nerve root exiting one level below (e.g., L4-L5 herniation compresses L5 root)

questions.question: What distinguishes structural scoliosis from postural scoliosis?
options: A. Structural scoliosis has a Cobb angle less than 10 degrees.
B. Structural scoliosis is always caused by injury.
C. Structural scoliosis is fixed and cannot be corrected by lateral flexion.
D. Structural scoliosis only occurs in the lumbar region.
questions.correctAnswer: C. Structural scoliosis is fixed and cannot be corrected by lateral flexion.

questions.question: What structural characteristic of the lumbar spine contributes to the pattern of nerve root compression seen in disc herniations?

D. The absence of the posterior longitudinal ligament
questions.correctAnswer: B. The oblique downward course of the nerve roots before exiting
